wwnorton.com/books/fault-...

I turned 18 in 1974 and was working as a summer intern at the USDA Rural Electrification Admin when Nixon resigned. Always meant to look back at the big arc, but, you know, moved to DK, back again, family issues, etc. This nails it.

posts.text:
I started the audiobook last weekend. (I have reservations about the narrator.) 

I have read the first two chapters, and so far it's excellent. Part fiction and simulation; part analysis of what we just went through. Are we ready for the Big One?

Sadly not.

Both are great but Graff's book is tremendous.  Can really highly recommend it!

Fiction: In Memoriam, by Alice Winn

Both are great but Graff's book is tremendous.  Can really highly recommend it!

posts.text: I‚Äôve been going back to Terry Pratchett‚Äôs Discworld novels, and I‚Äôm reminded how sharp they really are. Small Gods on the machinery of organized belief. Night Watch on how fragile institutions can be. Jingo on the absurd ease of sliding into war. The Truth on propaganda, media, and power.
posts.fullText: I‚Äôve been going back to Terry Pratchett‚Äôs Discworld novels, and I‚Äôm reminded how sharp they really are. Small Gods on the machinery of organized belief. Night Watch on how fragile institutions can be. Jingo on the absurd ease of sliding into war. The Truth on propaganda, media, and power.

posts.text: They get shelved as ‚Äúfantasy,‚Äù but they‚Äôre really some of the clearest, funniest, and most humane writing about politics and society I‚Äôve ever read. Pratchett had a way of making you laugh, then making you uneasy about why you were laughing.
posts.fullText: They get shelved as ‚Äúfantasy,‚Äù but they‚Äôre really some of the clearest, funniest, and most humane writing about politics and society I‚Äôve ever read. Pratchett had a way of making you laugh, then making you uneasy about why you were laughing.

posts.text: I was just re-listening to Wyrd Sisters which is one of my favourites. He has far more to say, indeed, about some serious subjects, than many authors (incl fantasy ones) who aren‚Äôt tagged as humorous

posts.text: Just finished The Last Lion: Winston Spencer Churchill: Alone, 1932‚Äì1940 by William Manchester. Fascinating look at the life of Churchill during the time no one thought the Nazis were a big deal. Not sure you need part one but Churchill‚Äôs time in the wilderness has some interesting lessons for us.

Not sure you need part one but Churchill‚Äôs time in the wilderness has some interesting lessons for us.

posts.text: A compelling look at a very complex figure that his superiors tried to simplify for their own greed. The man is much more interesting than the monk. (And I like the monk!)
posts.fullText:
A compelling look at a very complex figure that his superiors tried to simplify for their own greed. The man is much more interesting than the monk. (And I like the monk!)
[image alt: The cover of Mark Shaw's "Beneath the Mask of Holiness: Thomas Merton and the forbidden love affair that set him free." The lower third of the cover has a black and white picture of Thomas Merton from the chest up wearing the white robes and black scapular with cowl of a Trappist monk. He is a white male with a balding head of hair. He has his arms crossed and is looking to his right. He is standing in a field and you can see trees and hills in the background. The top third is a light beige back of an envelope with the title of the book. ]

posts.text: For the second time the nonfiction ‚ÄúOn Time and Water‚Äù by @andrimagnason.bsky.social, writer from Earth‚Äôs most resplendent island. Reading a second time because 1) I‚Äôm too dense and/or small-brained to have absorbed it all on just one reading, and 2) it‚Äôs enriching, illuminating, and important.

posts.text: Volume three ("Blue Mars") of Kim Stanley Robinson's Red Mars trilogy. Gotta be honest, it's a tough slog. KSR can be *very* wordy. The trick is to just skim over any paragraph covering more than one page.
posts.fullText: Volume three ("Blue Mars") of Kim Stanley Robinson's Red Mars trilogy. Gotta be honest, it's a tough slog. KSR can be *very* wordy. The trick is to just skim over any paragraph covering more than one page.

posts.text: Hahaha, yeah, that's how I remember the second and third volumes of that trilogy as well.
posts.fullText: Hahaha, yeah, that's how I remember the second and third volumes of that trilogy as well.

posts.text: After reading and thinking way too much about late-stage capitalism and tech billionaire escape fantasies, I went looking for something a bit more grounded in actual humanity. I found out that Michael Pollan had published this book, which had passed completely under my radar.
posts.fullText: After reading and thinking way too much about late-stage capitalism and tech billionaire escape fantasies, I went looking for something a bit more grounded in actual humanity. I found out that Michael Pollan had published this book, which had passed completely under my radar.

posts.text: michaelpollan.com/books/how-to...
posts.fullText: michaelpollan.com/books/how-to...

posts.text: It's a fascinating read. Don't misinterpret the title; it's curious science guy Pollan meditating on consciousness, ego, transience, and spirituality. Not something I necessarily would have expected from him, but he is incredibly gifted at it
posts.fullText: It's a fascinating read. Don't misinterpret the title; it's curious science guy Pollan meditating on consciousness, ego, transience, and spirituality. Not something I necessarily would have expected from him, but he is incredibly gifted at it

posts.text: Currently reading the 3rd (chronologically) Company Wars book by C. J. Cherryh. It's some such a great job of portraying a war with out any fighting and not glorifying it. It's mostly about the bureaucracy of dealing with refugees and how they are basically immediately treated as criminals...
posts.fullText: Currently reading the 3rd (chronologically) Company Wars book by C. J. Cherryh. It's some such a great job of portraying a war with out any fighting and not glorifying it. It's mostly about the bureaucracy of dealing with refugees and how they are basically immediately treated as criminals...

posts.text: Despite their only crime being fleeing from a war. I also really like the depiction of the struggles of making a semi-earth like world livable and balancing (or not balancing) the forced/volunteer work force to get it done. Really love her works and recommend all of them.
posts.fullText: Despite their only crime being fleeing from a war. I also really like the depiction of the struggles of making a semi-earth like world livable and balancing (or not balancing) the forced/volunteer work force to get it done. Really love her works and recommend all of them.

posts.text:
There is no Antimemetics Division was trippy as hell if you‚Äôre into, not exactly time travel, but memory loss constructed to create the same kind of time travel related mind fucks.

You must be ‚ÄúTenet obviously made perfect sense‚Äù tall to enjoy the ride though.
posts.fullText:
There is no Antimemetics Division was trippy as hell if you‚Äôre into, not exactly time travel, but memory loss constructed to create the same kind of time travel related mind fucks.

You must be ‚ÄúTenet obviously made perfect sense‚Äù tall to enjoy the ride though.

posts.text:
Found David Halberstam‚Äôs The Best & the Brightest , (1972) on a discard shelf. Reading this book reminds me, once again, what a sorry bunch of politicians/pentagon warhawks caused the needless loss of lives: Viet Nam. Two brothers served in that war. 
Halberstam was a wordsmith who pulls no punches.

posts.text: Just read Boschwitz's 1938 classic (re-released in 2021), The Passenger, and was struck by the eerie similarities between 1930s Germany and Trump's America. ICE grabbing people based on their appearance, for example, not unlike Nazis rounding up those who didn't look sufficiently Aryan.
posts.fullText: Just read Boschwitz's 1938 classic (re-released in 2021), The Passenger, and was struck by the eerie similarities between 1930s Germany and Trump's America. ICE grabbing people based on their appearance, for example, not unlike Nazis rounding up those who didn't look sufficiently Aryan.
